content.question: ​The Richter scale is a numerical scale that uses base <math alttext="10"><semantics><mn>10</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> logarithms for measuring an earthquake’s magnitude. The larger the number, the more intense the earthquake. For example, an earthquake with a magnitude of <math alttext="5.0"><semantics><mn>5.0</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> is <math alttext="10"><semantics><mn>10</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> times more intense than an earthquake with a magnitude of <math alttext="4.0"><semantics><mn>4.0</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>. Two well-known earthquakes occurred in the year 1906. The San Francisco earthquake had a magnitude of <math alttext="7.9"><semantics><mn>7.9</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>, and the Chile earthquake had a magnitude of <math alttext="8.2"><semantics><mn>8.2</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>. Approximately how many times more intense was the Chile earthquake than the San Francisco earthquake?
